elements.content: The assembly of mixed [1,1′;3′,1′′]­terphenyl-4,5′,4′′-tricarboxylic acid (H3TPTC) and [1,1′-biphenyl]-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC), 2,2′-diamino-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC-NH2), or 6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-5H-dibenzo­[d,f]­[1,3]­diazepine-3,9-dicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC-Urea) with Cu2+ ion generated the corresponding copper-paddlewheel-based metal–organic framework (MOF) [Cu5(TPTC)3(BPDC)0.5(H2O)5] (1), [Cu5(TPTC)3(BPDC-NH2)0.5(H2O)5] (1-NH 2 ), or [Cu5(TPTC)3(BPDC-Urea)0.5(H2O)5] (1-Urea). They are isostructural with hierarchical porosity, consisting of zero-dimensional cage (19.2 Å × 18.9 Å) and one-dimensional pillar channel (29.7 Å × 15.1 Å) in a manner of face sharing. Platon analyses revealed the porous volume ratios are 80.2%, 80.0%, and 77.8% for 1, 1-NH 2 , and for 1-Urea, respectively. Thermogravimetric measurements suggested 53, 51, and 48 wt % guest molecules in 1, 1-NH 2 , and 1-Urea, respectively. 1-NH 2 and 1-Urea were precisely functionalized via the introduction of amino and urea functional groups into the pillar channels. The constructed MOF 1-Urea, incorporating both exposed copper active sites and accessible urea functional groups to substrates, presents high efficiency on catalytic CO2 cycloaddition with propene oxide to produce cyclic carbonate in the yield of 98% with a TOF value of 136 h–1 at 1 atm and room temperature. This synergic effect provides a new strategy for designing high-efficient catalysts for CO2 chemical conversion under ambient conditions.

The constructed MOF, incorporating both exposed metal active sites and accessible urea groups, presents high efficiency on catalytic epoxides cycloaddition with CO2 to produce cyclic carbonates under ambient conditions.

elements.content: CO2 is one of the most important greenhouse gases, and its accumulation in air may cause climatic and environmental effects. Thus, the conversion of CO2 into a wide range of chemical materials is in high demand. Although great advances have been achieved in this field, it is still a considerable challenge to convert CO2 into other chemicals under mild reaction conditions due to the thermodynamically stable and inert nature of CO2. To resolve this problem, many advanced catalysts have been developed. Among them, porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are regarded as an excellent platform for CO2 conversion because of their unique features such as large surface areas, large porous volumes, diverse building blocks, and tunable porous structures. To endow MOFs with catalytic activity for CO2 conversion, active sites that can adsorb and activate CO2 and/or substrates as well as large porous channels that benefit in material transport should be incorporated into the frameworks. It was found that metal-paddlewheel-based MOFs with unsaturated metal sites as Lewis acids could highly increase the adsorption and catalytic conversion of CO2 at various conditions. Ma, Zhao, and their co-workers have demonstrated that the introduction of nitrogen species with Lewis basicity, metal ions with strong coordination ability, and weak acidic functional groups into the copper-paddlewheel-based MOFs could significantly enhance the catalytic activity for the reaction of CO2 with epoxide under ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

CO2 is one of the most important greenhouse gases, and its accumulation in air may cause climatic and environmental effects. Thus, the conversion of CO2 into a wide range of chemical materials is in high demand. Although great advances have been achieved in this field, it is still a considerable challenge to convert CO2 into other chemicals under mild reaction conditions due to the thermodynamically stable and inert nature of CO2. To resolve this problem, many advanced catalysts have been developed. Among them, porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are regarded as an excellent platform for CO2 conversion because of their unique features such as large surface areas, large porous volumes, diverse building blocks, and tunable porous structures. To endow MOFs with catalytic activity for CO2 conversion, active sites that can adsorb and activate CO2 and/or substrates as well as large porous channels that benefit in material transport should be incorporated into the frameworks. It was found that metal-paddlewheel-based MOFs with unsaturated metal sites as Lewis acids could highly increase the adsorption and catalytic conversion of CO2 at various conditions. Ma, Zhao, and their co-workers have demonstrated that the introduction of nitrogen species with Lewis basicity, metal ions with strong coordination ability, and weak acidic functional groups into the copper-paddlewheel-based MOFs could significantly enhance the catalytic activity for the reaction of CO2 with epoxide under ambient conditions.

elements.content: Recent studies showed that the assembly of mixed tritopic and ditopic aromatic acids with the classical secondary building units (SBUs) generated the ultrahigh porous MOFs without interpenetration (see Table S1 in the Supporting Information). Cu-paddlewheel SBU possesses the unique 4 or 6-connective mode and has been widely used to fabricate porous MOFs with various dimensionality. We are aware that the strategy for mixed tritopic and ditopic aromatic acids has rarely been utilized in construction of copper-paddlewheel-based MOFs so far. Considering the linker length compatibility, the mixture of [1,1′′;3′,1′′]­terphenyl-4,5′,4′′-tricarboxylic acid (H3TPTC) and [1,1′-biphenyl]-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC) () was first used to assemble with [Cu2(COO)4] SBU to generate a new [Cu2(COO)4]-based MOF material [Cu5(TPTC)3(BPDC)0.5(H2O)5] (1). 1 possesses unique hierarchical porosity, consisting of zero-dimensional (0D) cages and one-dimensional (1D) channels in mesoporous scale with BPDC2– as pillars. Furthermore, amino and urea functional groups were precisely introduced into the 1D channels via decoration of H2BPDC pillar ligand to produce [Cu2(COO)4]-based MOF materials [Cu5(TPTC)3(BPDC-NH2)0.5(H2O)5] (1-NH 2 , where H2BPDC-NH2 is 2,2′-diamino-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid) and [Cu5(TPTC)3(BPDC-Urea)0.5(H2O)5] (1-Urea, where H2BPDC-Urea is 6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-5H-dibenzo­[d,f]­[1,3]­diazepine-3,9-dicarboxylic acid). 1-Urea, incorporating both unsaturated Cu2+ active sites and accessible urea groups to substrates, exhibits high efficiency on catalytic CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides at 1 atm and room temperature.

elements.content: The linkers of H3TPTC and H2BPDC and other reagents as well as solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. 1H NMR spectra were recorded with a Bruker AV 400. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for the single phase polycrystalline samples were performed on a SEIKO Instruments/EXSTAR TG/DTA 6300 under N2 atmosphere in the range of 30–800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 powder X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analysis was measured by PerkinElmer Optima 8300 ICP-OES spectrometers. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 4000–450 cm–1 on a Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer using the KBr disc technique.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Techniques

The linkers of H3TPTC and H2BPDC and other reagents as well as solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. 1H NMR spectra were recorded with a Bruker AV 400. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for the single phase polycrystalline samples were performed on a SEIKO Instruments/EXSTAR TG/DTA 6300 under N2 atmosphere in the range of 30-800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 powder X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analysis was measured by PerkinElmer Optima 8300 ICP-OES spectrometers. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 4000-450 cm-1 on a Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer using the KBr disc technique.

elements.content: Ligands H2BPDC-NH2 and dimethyl 2,2′-diamino-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4,4′-dicarboxylate (BPDC-NH2-OMe) were synthesized according to the reported procedure. Ligands H2BPDC-Urea and dimethyl 6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-5H-dibenzo­[d,f]­[1,3]­diazepine-3,9-dicarboxylate (BPDC-Urea-OMe) were synthesized according to the literature with some modifications. H2BPDC-NH2 or BPDC-NH2-OMe (3.3 mmol) was dissolved in a 50 mL HOAc, then urea (6.6 mmol) was added to the solution. The mixture was stirred at 130 °C overnight. The resulted precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and dried in air. For H2BPDC-Urea, yield: 90%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz) δ 9.13 (s, 2H), 7.73 (s, 2H), 7.72 (d, 2H), 7.63 (d, 2H). For BPDC-Urea-OMe, yield: 79%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz) δ 9.16 (s, 2H), 7.76 (d, 2H), 7.75 (dd, 2H), 7.67 (d, 2H), 3.89 (s, 6H).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Ditopic Linkers

Ligands H2BPDC-NH2 and dimethyl 2,2'-diamino-[1,1'-biphenyl]-4,4'-dicarboxylate (BPDC-NH2-OMe) were synthesized according to the reported procedure. Ligands H2BPDC-Urea and dimethyl 6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-5H-dibenzo[d,f][1,3]diazepine-3,9-dicarboxylate (BPDC-Urea-OMe) were synthesized according to the literature with some modifications. H2BPDC-NH2 or BPDC-NH2-OMe (3.3 mmol) was dissolved in a 50 mL HOAc, then urea (6.6 mmol) was added to the solution. The mixture was stirred at 130 °C overnight. The resulted precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and dried in air. For H2BPDC-Urea, yield: 90%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz) δ 9.13 (s, 2H), 7.73 (s, 2H), 7.72 (d, 2H), 7.63 (d, 2H). For BPDC-Urea-OMe, yield: 79%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz) δ 9.16 (s, 2H), 7.76 (d, 2H), 7.75 (dd, 2H), 7.67 (d, 2H), 3.89 (s, 6H).

elements.content: Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.024 g, 0.1 mmol), H3TPTC (0.018 g, 0.05 mmol), and H2BPDC (0.008 g, 0.03 mmol) were added to a solution of DMA-H2O (6 and 0.5 mL), then HOAc (0.1 mL) was added under stirring. The solution was transferred into a 15 mL autoclave. The reaction solution was heated at 80 °C for 24 h, then cooled to room temperature. The blue bock-shaped crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 61% (0.05g) based on Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O. The crystal product was washed with DMA and kept in DMA solution. FT-IR (KBr, 4000–400 cm–1) 3552 (vs), 3046 (w), 2963 (w), 1696 (m), 1606 (m), 1575 (m), 1532 (s),1402 (vs), 1318 (w), 1182 (w), 1016 (m), 856 (m), 811 (w), 773 (s), 743 (m), 710 (w), 672 (w), 511 (w).

elements.content: The epoxide substrate (12.5 mmol), catalyst (0.25 mol % per Cu2 paddlewheel units, activated 1, 1-NH 2 , or 1-Urea; see the Supporting Information), and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB, 0.9 mmol, 7.2 mol %) were taken in a Schlenk tube with CO2 supplied in balloon (1 atm). The reaction solution was magnetic stirred at room temperature (∼25 °C) for 36 h. Then, an aliquot of the reaction mixture was dissolved in CDCl3, and the 1H NMR was recorded for the calculation of yield.
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure for the Cycloaddition of Epoxides with CO2 

The epoxide substrate (12.5 mmol), catalyst (0.25 mol % per Cu2 paddlewheel units, activated 1, 1-NH  2 , or 1-Urea; see the Supporting Information), and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB, 0.9 mmol, 7.2 mol %) were taken in a Schlenk tube with CO2 supplied in balloon (1 atm). The reaction solution was magnetic stirred at room temperature (~25 °C) for 36 h. Then, an aliquot of the reaction mixture was dissolved in CDCl3, and the 1H NMR was recorded for the calculation of yield.

elements.content: The diffraction data of 1, 1-NH 2 , and 1-Urea were collected on an Oxford Xcalibur, Sapphire3, Gemini ultra CCD diffractometer equipped with monochromatic CuKα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 298(2) K (for 1 and 1-NH 2 ) or 150(2) K (for 1-Urea). The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects (SAINT), and empirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied (SADABS). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with SHELXTL program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms were calculated and refined as a riding model. The hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules were located from difference maps. The disordered guest molecules in 1, 1-NH 2 , and 1-Urea could not be modeled and were treated by the SQUEEZE routine. The crystallographic details are provided in Table S2 (Supporting Information), and selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S3 (Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Crystallography

The diffraction data of 1, 1-NH  2 , and 1-Urea were collected on an Oxford Xcalibur, Sapphire3, Gemini ultra CCD diffractometer equipped with monochromatic CuKα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 298(2) K (for 1 and 1-NH  2 ) or 150(2) K (for 1-Urea). The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects (SAINT), and empirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied (SADABS). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with SHELXTL program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms were calculated and refined as a riding model. The hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules were located from difference maps. The disordered guest molecules in 1, 1-NH  2 , and 1-Urea could not be modeled and were treated by the SQUEEZE routine. The crystallographic details are provided in Table S2 (Supporting Information), and selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S3 (Supporting Information).

elements.content: Tritopic and ditopic aromatic acids have been widely employed to construct MOFs. Yaghi and co-workers first reported the Cu-paddlewheel-based MOFs constructed by H2BPDC ligand, in which interpenetrating two-dimensional square nets were formed because the dimensions of the square unit were too large to allow interpenetration. Moreover, the first example of [Cu2(COO)4] SBU-based MOF (UMCM-151) connected by TPTC3– ligand was reported in 2010, which exhibits large channels with dimensions of 13.0 Å × 30.4 Å, but collapses upon removal of solvents. Herein, we assembled the mixture of tritopic and ditopic aromatic acids with Cu-paddlewheel SBU to produce a new typical porous MOF (). The solvothermal reaction of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O, H3TPTC, and H2BPDC in a solution of DMA and H2O in the presence of HOAc at 80 °C for 24 h resulted in compound 1. It is a Cu-paddlewheel-based MOF with hierarchical porosity.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Characterization

Tritopic and ditopic aromatic acids have been widely employed to construct MOFs. Yaghi and co-workers first reported the Cu-paddlewheel-based MOFs constructed by H2BPDC ligand, in which interpenetrating two-dimensional square nets were formed because the dimensions of the square unit were too large to allow interpenetration. Moreover, the first example of [Cu2(COO)4] SBU-based MOF (UMCM-151) connected by TPTC3- ligand was reported in 2010, which exhibits large channels with dimensions of 13.0 Å × 30.4 Å, but collapses upon removal of solvents. Herein, we assembled the mixture of tritopic and ditopic aromatic acids with Cu-paddlewheel SBU to produce a new typical porous MOF (). The solvothermal reaction of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O, H3TPTC, and H2BPDC in a solution of DMA and H2O in the presence of HOAc at 80 °C for 24 h resulted in compound 1. It is a Cu-paddlewheel-based MOF with hierarchical porosity.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in orthorhombic crystal system, Cmcm space group. In each asymmetry unit, 5/2 Cu2+, 3/2 TPTC3–, 1/4 BPDC2–, and 5/2 H2O are found (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Each Cu2+ is five coordinated by oxygen atom, four from carboxylate, and one from water ligand. Three different kinds of Cu-paddlewheel SBUs are present in 1. As shown in a, one is constructed by two p-benzoate and one m-carboxylate groups from three TPTC3– and one p-benzoate from BPDC2–. The second one consists of four p-benzoate of four TPTC3– ligands. The third is composed of two p-benzoate and two m-carboxylate groups from four TPTC3– ligands. These are different from UMCM-151, where the p-benzoate and m-carboxylate groups are segregated into two paddlewheels. In addition, two kinds of different structural units A and B are found in 1. Unit A is a hexagon-shaped 1D channel with a dimension of 29.7 Å × 15.1 Å (accounting of van der Waals radii, b), which is comparable to the large channel observed in UMCM-151 (13.0 Å × 30.4 Å). The 1D channel is assembled by the connection of four [Cu2(COO)4] SBUs with eight p-benzoate groups from the TPTC3– ligands. A BPDC2– ligand links two [Cu2(COO)4] SBUs as a pillar in the middle of each 1D channel, and the distance between the two neighboring pillars is about 10 Å. Different from unit A, unit B is 0D cage-like structure with an inner sphere of 19.2 Å × 18.9 Å (c). It is assembled via the connection of TPTC3– ligands with [Cu2(COO)4] SBUs. Units A and B connect each other via sharing face (d) to form a 3D structure (e). Interestingly, the introduction of BPDC2– ligand caused the transformation of 1D channel from oblong shape in UMCM-151 to a regular hexagon shape in 1. Structural analysis by Platon software revealed that the accessible pore volume in 1 was about 80.2%. Most importantly, the pillars anchored in the middle of the channels provide the possibility to introduce functional groups for catalytic reactions.

elements.content: Topological analysis of 1 was applied by reducing multidimensional structure to a simple node and linker net. On the basis of the simplification principle, ligands TPTC3– and BPDC2– connect to three and two Cu-paddlewheel SBUs, donating as 3- and 2-connector, respectively. Each Cu-paddlewheel SBU connects four carboxylate groups and thus can be regarded as a 4-connector (). Topological analysis using TOPOS software revealed a 3, 3, 4, 4, 4-c type network with the point (Schläfli) symbol of {5·6·8}4{52·62·92}­{52·83·10}2{6·82}2{62·82·102}2.

elements.content: The TGA measurement of 1 (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information) showed 53% weight loss from room temperature to 200 °C, which corresponded to the loss of free guest molecules within the pore of 1. The TGA curve went into a plateau in the temperature range of 200–300 °C. Thereafter, the decomposition of the framework of 1 was observed. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern for bulk sample of 1 was consistent with the simulated PXRD pattern deduced from SCXRD data (see Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). 1H NMR analysis for the digest sample of 1 revealed the ratio of H3TPTC:H2BPDC was near 6:1 (see Figure S4 in the Supporting Information), which was consistent with the one deduced from the SCXRD data.

elements.content: Structural analysis showed that 1 possesses large 1D channels and the pillar BPDC2– ligand anchors in the middle of the channel. These provide the possibility to modify the 1D channels for catalytic reaction via the introduction of functional groups into BPDC2– ligand. Amino and urea groups have been proved to be a significant enhancement in adsorption and conversion of CO2. Herein, two amino groups were introduced via nitration then reduction, affording the H2BPDC-NH2 ligand. Furthermore, the H2BPDC-NH2 ligand was further converted into H2BPDC-Urea ligand by reacting with urea in HOAc solution (see the and a). Indeed, when these ligands were used to react with Cu­(NO3)2 instead of H2BPDC in the presence of H3TPTC ligand under the identical conditions, two new compounds 1-NH 2 and 1-Urea were obtained, respectively. SCXRD analyses displayed that they are isostructural with 1 (see Figures S5 and S6 in the Supporting Information). As expected, BPDC-NH2 2– and BPDC-Urea2– ligands indeed anchored in the 1D channels as pillars (b–d). No significant change in the dimensions of the 1D channel was observed due to the identical length of the three ditopic linkers. However, the microenvironments within the 1D channels are different. In 1-NH 2 , the two amino groups sit respectively in two sites along the biphenyl axis (see c). In contrast, the urea group is set in one site in 1-Urea (d). This arrangement is believed to facilitate the formation of multi hydrogen-bond interactions between hosts and guests (vide infra). The introduction of amino and urea groups slightly reduced the pore volume from 80.2% for 1 to 80.0% for 1-NH 2 and 77.8% for 1-Urea. The PXRD patterns of 1-NH 2 and 1-Urea were consistent with the corresponding PXRD patterns deduced from their SCXRD data (Figures S7 and S8). 1H NMR analysis for the digest samples of 1-NH 2 and 1-Urea revealed that the ratios of TPTC3–:BPDC-NH2 2– and TPTC3–:BPDC-Urea2– were all in 6.2:1 (Figures S9 and S10), which were stoichiometric consistent with their formula deduced from SCXRD.

elements.content: TGA experiments were also carried out to evaluate the thermal stabilities of 1-NH 2 and 1-Urea, respectively. Similar cases were observed with 1 (see Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). The exchange of guest and coordinate water molecules was carried out in DCM solvent and used to activate the MOFs for catalysis. The significant color changes indicated the guest and coordinate aqua molecules were removed by DCM molecules (see Figure S11 in the Supporting Information). Furthermore, PXRD experiments revealed the frameworks of the three compounds remain upon exchange by DCM (see Figures S12–S14 in the Supporting Information). However, the attempts to remove all guest molecules to measure the surface area led to the framework collapse under reduced pressure. To further evaluate the porosity of the frameworks, the three MOFs were soaked in the solution of ibuprofen, a relative larger molecule, respectively (see experiment in the Supporting Information). After washing with cyclohexane to remove the ibuprofen adsorbed on surface, the significant color changes indicated that ibuprofen was adsorbed into the frameworks (see Figure S11 in in the Supporting Information). The further analysis by 1H NMR spectroscopy revealed that the contents of ibuprofen adsorbed in 1, 1-NH 2 , and 1-Urea were 0.65, 0.70, and 0.61 g/g, respectively (see Table S4 and Figure S15). PXRD experiments also confirmed that the frameworks still remain upon adsorption of ibuprofen (see Figures S12–S14 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Plenty of MOFs have been used as heterogeneous catalysts for the cycloaddition reactions of epoxides with CO2. However, most of catalytic reactions were carried out under high temperature (>80 °C) and high CO2 pressures (>7 atm). This increased the energy consumption and production costs. The solvent exchange experiment in DCM showed that the guest and coordinated aqua molecules in the MOFs would be completely removed. This can be used to activate MOFs. The activated MOFs with exposed Lewis acid sites in the framework would be a highly promising catalyst for CO2 conversion reactions. This encouraged us to examine its catalytic activity for the cycloaddition reactions of epoxides with CO2 to produce carbonates that have been widely applied in pharmaceutical and electrochemical industries. In the meantime, the benchmark Cu-paddlewheel MOF HKUST-1 was also taken as a catalyst for comparison. Propene oxide (PO) was chosen as a model substrate for coupling with CO2 (1 atm, supplied in balloon) to produce carbonates in the presence of 1 (0.25 mol % per Cu2 paddlewheel units) as a catalyst and TBAB (7.2 mol %) as a co-catalyst at room temperature. To our delight, cyclic carbonate product afforded in yield of 40% in 36 h with a turnover frequency (TOF) value of 56 h–1 per Cu2 cluster (see ). For HKUST-1 catalyst, the yield was 35% with a TOF value of 49 h–1 per Cu2 cluster under the identical conditions, indicating that their catalytic activities were comparable. The control experiments showed that TBAB was indispensable for the reaction. Only 18% cyclic carbonate was obtained in the absence of MOF catalyst under the same conditions, and no cyclic carbonate was obtained in the absence of TBAB. When compound 1-NH 2 was used instead of 1, the yield of cyclic carbonate slightly increased to 50% with a TOF value of 69 h–1 per Cu2 cluster under the identical conditions. Interestingly, when compound 1-Urea was used as a catalyst, an excellent yield of cyclic carbonate in 98% with a TOF value of 136 h–1 per Cu2 cluster was obtained under the identical conditions. To compare the catalytic activity of 1-Urea with the recently reported excellent catalyst (JUC-1000) for cycloaddition of PO with CO2 under ambient conditions, the amount of co-catalyst TABA was increased to 10% (see entry 7 in ). We found that PO was almost completely converted into cyclic carbonate within 30 h. In this case, the TOF value was 156 h–1 per Cu2 cluster, which was comparable to that of JUC-1000 (160 h–1, see entry 14 in ), but lower than that of Cu4L8 (200 h–1, see entry 15 in ).

Catalytic Reaction of the MOFs

Plenty of MOFs have been used as heterogeneous catalysts for the cycloaddition reactions of epoxides with CO2. However, most of catalytic reactions were carried out under high temperature (>80 °C) and high CO2 pressures (>7 atm). This increased the energy consumption and production costs. The solvent exchange experiment in DCM showed that the guest and coordinated aqua molecules in the MOFs would be completely removed. This can be used to activate MOFs. The activated MOFs with exposed Lewis acid sites in the framework would be a highly promising catalyst for CO2 conversion reactions. This encouraged us to examine its catalytic activity for the cycloaddition reactions of epoxides with CO2 to produce carbonates that have been widely applied in pharmaceutical and electrochemical industries. In the meantime, the benchmark Cu-paddlewheel MOF HKUST-1 was also taken as a catalyst for comparison. Propene oxide (PO) was chosen as a model substrate for coupling with CO2 (1 atm, supplied in balloon) to produce carbonates in the presence of 1 (0.25 mol % per Cu2 paddlewheel units) as a catalyst and TBAB (7.2 mol %) as a co-catalyst at room temperature. To our delight, cyclic carbonate product afforded in yield of 40% in 36 h with a turnover frequency (TOF) value of 56 h-1 per Cu2 cluster (see ). For HKUST-1 catalyst, the yield was 35% with a TOF value of 49 h-1 per Cu2 cluster under the identical conditions, indicating that their catalytic activities were comparable. The control experiments showed that TBAB was indispensable for the reaction. Only 18% cyclic carbonate was obtained in the absence of MOF catalyst under the same conditions, and no cyclic carbonate was obtained in the absence of TBAB. When compound 1-NH  2  was used instead of 1, the yield of cyclic carbonate slightly increased to 50% with a TOF value of 69 h-1 per Cu2 cluster under the identical conditions. Interestingly, when compound 1-Urea was used as a catalyst, an excellent yield of cyclic carbonate in 98% with a TOF value of 136 h-1 per Cu2 cluster was obtained under the identical conditions. To compare the catalytic activity of 1-Urea with the recently reported excellent catalyst (JUC-1000) for cycloaddition of PO with CO2 under ambient conditions, the amount of co-catalyst TABA was increased to 10% (see entry 7 in ). We found that PO was almost completely converted into cyclic carbonate within 30 h. In this case, the TOF value was 156 h-1 per Cu2 cluster, which was comparable to that of JUC-1000 (160 h-1, see entry 14 in ), but lower than that of Cu4L8 (200 h-1, see entry 15 in ).

Reaction conditions: Epoxide (12.5 mmol), catalyst (0.25 mol % per paddlewheel unit), and TBAB (7.2 mol %) at RT (∼25 °C) for 36 h, yields were determined by 1H NMR.

In absence of TBAB.

TBAB was 10 mol % for 30 h.

TBAB was 10 mol % for 48 h (see ref ).

The comparison of the yields obtained from the four catalysts clearly revealed that 1-Urea showed remarkably higher performance for catalytic PO cycloaddition with CO2 under the identical conditions (see ). With a similar pore size and the same embedded Lewis acid metal sites in compounds 1, 1-NH 2 , and 1-Urea, the higher catalytic activity of 1-Urea may be attributed to the modification of the micro environment in 1D channels via the introduction of urea functional groups into the framework. The urea groups may activate PO substrate via formation of multi hydrogen bond interactions. To certify the catalytic activity of these functional groups, BPDC-NH2-OMe and BPDC-Urea-OMe, esters of the ditopic ligands were used as catalysts to catalyze the cycloaddition reaction individually under the same conditions (entries 8 and 9, ). It was found that both BPDC-NH2-OMe and BPDC-Urea-OMe could catalyze the reaction individually, affording cyclic carbonate in yields of 41% and 37%, respectively. The lower catalytic activity of BPDC-Urea-OMe may be attributed to its poor solubility in PO. Therefore, the higher catalytic activity of 1-Urea may benefit from the synergic effect in the framework. Besides the open Cu2+ metal sites that bind to PO substrate, the reaction can also be activated by these urea functional groups via forming strong hydrogen bonds with epoxide ring (see b), making the reaction highly efficient. In contrast, the hydrogen bonds formed between the amino groups and epoxide are relative weak (see a). Thus, the catalytic activity of 1-NH 2 was relative inferior.

elements.content: According to the above analyses, a potential mechanism for CO2 conversion was proposed, as shown in . The cycloaddition reaction was initiated by the binding of epoxide to the Lewis acidic site of [Cu2(COO)4] and urea groups of 1-Urea via multi hydrogen bonds to enhance the electrophilicity of the epoxide. Subsequently, the Br– from TBAB attacked the less-hindered and strong electrophilic carbon atom of the activated epoxide, followed by opening ring of epoxide. The resultant opened ring anions intermediates reacted with the surrounding CO2 rapidly to produce alkylcarbonate anions, which were further converted into the cyclic carbonates through the closed ring step. The introduction of urea group in 1-urea is believed to be more efficient activation of epoxide via formation of multi hydrogen bonds to initiate the cycloaddition reaction, leading to highly catalytic activity for chemical conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates under ambient conditions. In contrast, complex 1 and HKUST-1 only catalyzed the cycloaddition reaction by Cu2+ ions as Lewis acidic centers.

elements.content: Epoxide substrates with various molecular size were employed to check the catalytic generality of compound 1-Urea for the cycloaddition reactions with CO2 to produce cyclic carbonates under the same reaction conditions. The yields of cyclic carbonates decreased to 78%, 50%, and 43% for butylene oxide, 1,2-epoxy-3-allyloxypropane, and glycidyl phenyl ether, respectively (). This may be related to the slow diffusion of large-sized substrates into the framework with the increase of molecule size from 4.2 × 2.6 × 1.8 Å3 of propylene oxide to 9.4 × 4.3 × 2.3 Å3 of glycidyl phenyl ether. Moreover, the interaction strength between the substrates and the active sites may also affect the catalytic activity. In our case, compound 1-Urea possesses a large pore size (29.7 Å × 15.1 Å) to allow the epoxide substrates to pass through. Therefore, the reaction may differ from the interaction degree between the epoxide substrates and the active sites in 1-Urea. To prove this hypothesis, the cyclohexene oxide was selected as a substrate because it is a moderate size molecule but a 1,2-disbutituted epoxide compound different from the other 1-sbutituted epoxide compounds. The reaction yield sharply decreased to 19% under the identical conditions (entry 13, ), even lower than that of glycidyl phenyl ether (entry 12, ). This indicated that the interaction strength of epoxide substrates and Lewis acid metal sites as well as the urea functional groups may be the major factor that governed the cycloaddition reactions of epoxide with CO2. These observations also indicated that the reactions took place within the framework.

elements.content: The highly catalytic activity of 1-Urea encouraged us to examine its recyclability, which was tested using the cycloaddition reaction of PO with CO2 to produce carbonate as an example. After each reaction, catalyst 1-Urea was recovered by centrifugation, washed with DCM three times, and dried. The PXRD result showed that the framework 1-Urea was still maintained in one cycle reaction (Figure S8c). The ICP-OES analysis of the digested organic solution showed that tiny Cu2+ ions (∼0.02%) released into the solution during the reaction, indicating that catalyst 1-Urea seemed to catalyze the cycloaddition reaction in a heterogeneous manner. To verify the reusability, the recovered 1-Urea was reused to catalyze the next cycloaddition of PO with CO2 under the same conditions. The yields of carbonate slowly decreased from 98% to 85%, 74%, 66%, and 37% (Figure S16), respectively. The PXRD results showed that the crystalline disappeared after 5 runs (Figure S8d), indicating that the framework collapsed gradually. This may be attributed to the large accessible pore volume in 1-Urea (77.8%). The stability of the framework reduced when the guest molecules were exchanged or removed.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have demonstrated that the assembly of mixed tritopic and ditopic aromatic acids with Cu2+ ion would generate copper-paddlewheel-based MOFs with hierarchical porosity. MOFs could be precisely functionalized via the introduction of functional groups in the linkers. The constructed MOF, incorporating both exposed metal active sites and accessible urea groups for strong hydrogen bonding, presents high efficiency on catalytic epoxides cycloaddition with CO2 to produce cyclic carbonates under ambient conditions. This synergic effect provides a new strategy for designing high-efficient catalysts for CO2 chemical conversion during the process of the carbon fixation under ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have demonstrated that the assembly of mixed tritopic and ditopic aromatic acids with Cu2+ ion would generate copper-paddlewheel-based MOFs with hierarchical porosity. MOFs could be precisely functionalized via the introduction of functional groups in the linkers. The constructed MOF, incorporating both exposed metal active sites and accessible urea groups for strong hydrogen bonding, presents high efficiency on catalytic epoxides cycloaddition with CO2 to produce cyclic carbonates under ambient conditions. This synergic effect provides a new strategy for designing high-efficient catalysts for CO2 chemical conversion during the process of the carbon fixation under ambient conditions.

cln_elements.content:
Ligands H2BPDC-NH2 and dimethyl 2,2′-diamino-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4,4′-dicarboxylate (BPDC-NH2-OMe) were synthesized according to the reported procedure. Ligands H2BPDC-Urea and dimethyl 6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-5H-dibenzo­[d,f]­[1,3]­diazepine-3,9-dicarboxylate (BPDC-Urea-OMe) were synthesized according to the literature with some modifications. H2BPDC-NH2 or BPDC-NH2-OMe (3.3 mmol) was dissolved in a 50 mL HOAc, then urea (6.6 mmol) was added to the solution. The mixture was stirred at 130 °C overnight. Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.024 g, 0.1 mmol), H3TPTC (0.018 g, 0.05 mmol), and H2BPDC (0.008 g, 0.03 mmol) were added to a solution of DMA-H2O (6 and 0.5 mL), then HOAc (0.1 mL) was added under stirring.
